answers.answer: Pretty much just watch your sugar intake. I have GD and I'm not a diet plus working out and my sugar have been normal.
Im 30 weeks with GSD been checking my sugars as im told to but ive been normal range just stay away from the sweet stuff and bad carbs
Im 30 weeks with GSD been checking my sugars as im told to but ive been normal range just stay away from the sweet stuff and bad carbs

Not just sugar. But carbs. All about portion control. I got diagnosed with gd. Had to check my sugars 4 times a day. Eventually had to go on some meds to keep my sugars in better check.  Sugars werent horrible, usually 130s-160s lunch and dinner time. I took myself off the meds and was controlling my sugars with better discipline lol. And walking more after I feel like I've eaten a little too much carbs. I guess being pregnant doesn't mean you can eat whatever you want haha
I would avoid juices and pops. Also only eat fruit as a snack. I myself have had to adjust my food intake. I follow the food guidelines to a t.
Thank you so much for the info .

Be careful with the fruits too. they're naturally high in sugar too. See if you can find like the plate method of eating or something like that lol. It shows how much of each you should be eating. The diabetes nurse I saw at my high risk ob gave me a meal plan of how many carbs should be eaten at each meal with less eaten in the morning. And snacks in between. Usually pair carbs with tons of protein to keep you more stabilized

Its not really all your sugars. I can eat cookies and milk and my sugars will be fine but if I eat a big burrito it will go up from the tortillas, beans and rice which are all carbs. Watch your carbs. Oh and don't eat cereal the one thing that makes my sugars go through the roof is a bowl of cereal.

Hi,I'm 33w tomorrow and I'm diagnosed with Gestational Diabetes.I did pretty well on diet, but kept failing my before breakfast morning blood sugar test.Then occassionally I would fail my bloodsugar test after dinner (not often, but it did happen).So I started on insulin two weeks ago, it really works beautifully.Gestational Diabetes has many side-effects, and severe hunger is one. Which I have.I have never been hungry like this before.. I'm usually not big on food and usually eat poorly, small portions and skipping meals etc etc.. and never usually have apetite or real hunger feelings.So to me, this is quite new.What I find helping is -occupy your mind, get busy, do your exercises.. healthy small snacks.Trick yourself that you're full, drink heaps of water ;)It is essential to stay on top of your bloodsugar levels, for your own and your baby's long life's health. Yes.Testing your blood all the time and if you also on top of that take insulin, even worse.Keeping a logbook for food and sugar level readings.. it is like your life is all about it.Planning all your meals carefully.It is HARD and I sometimes feel that people don't understand it..but remember, all this effort is for your baby who really needs it and for you.Also, only 1/3 continue to have diabetes after delivery.. so it is most likely time limited.Another positive thing is that you'll not be overdue.Your OB/doctor will ensure you don't go past your due date.. so you'll have a better idea when you got your baby :)
Haha. Exactly what she said. They want my baby out at 38 and half weeks. Which will be next wed! Can't wait to see her.

question: I never liked sweets, I do exercise and eat healthy just this last 2months I started craving sweets. I did a glucose test and came back positive normal 140 i was 170. Any advice on this or what foods to avoid or a certain diet I can do while I do my next 3hr glucose test on monday . Has anyone had it even after pregnancy? Doc said it should go away .
title: gestional diabetes at 32 weeks . any advice?
